thread.title: Irish privacy watchdog to probe Facebook data transfers
thread.title_full: Irish privacy watchdog to probe Facebook data transfers

title: Irish privacy watchdog to probe Facebook data transfers
text:
Published: Oct 20, 2015 10:25 a.m. ET Share 
Facebook probe is the first test of a recent EU ruling on privacy and data transfers. 
By Bloomberg Facebook case is first test of an EU court ruling on data transfers 
Ireland’s privacy watchdog will now probe how much access the U.S. government has to Europeans’ Facebook profiles--and whether that means Facebook should be forced to keep Europeans’ data in Europe. 
The Irish Data Protection Commissioner promised in Irish court Tuesday that it will speedily investigate a complaint against Facebook alleging the social network violated the privacy rights of European residents by sending their data to servers in the U.S., in the first concrete application of a ruling two weeks ago by the European Union’s top court invalidating a 15-year-old trans-Atlantic pact called “Safe Harbor” that had protected such transfers. 
The Facebook FB, -0.12% probe could become a bellwether for thousands of companies that send personal information about Europeans to the U.S. in order to do everything from selling online advertising to maintaining corporate personnel files. Privacy advocates say the EU court ruling closes a gaping hole in individuals’ online privacy, but companies say the ruling will raise their legal costs and possibly hobble their ability to operate in Europe by forcing them to locate more data on European soil. 
It remains unclear how long the Irish probe will take, or if it will be overtaken by efforts by the U.S. and the EU to replace the invalidated Safe Harbor agreement with a new pact that addresses EU concerns. Last week, EU privacy regulators--including the Irish regulator--gave negotiators for the EU and U.S. until the end of January to come up with a new agreement, before starting “coordinated enforcement actions.” 
The privacy probe stems from a 2013 complaint Austrian privacy activist Max Schrems lodged with the privacy regulator in Ireland, where Facebook has its EU headquarters. Schrems argued that leaks from former U.S. National Security Agency contractor Edward Snowden showed his data wasn’t being protected by Facebook. But the watchdog refused to investigate at the time, citing the now defunct trans-Atlantic data pact, and Schrems appealed in Irish court.
